Homage to the Buddha Well Purified' ÅšÄriputra!
To summarize, the present buddhas' teachings are inexhaustible.
ÅšÄriputra!

It is like the worlds of the east, south, west, and north, the zenith and nadir, and the four intermediate directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, all of those worlds, from the bottom of the water to the peak of existence, filled with fine dust.
ÅšÄriputra!
What do you think? Can the number of those fine dust motes be known?
ÅšÄriputra said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:ğŸ”½ÅšÄriputra!
The ÅšÄkyamuni Buddhas with the same name as mine who are presently in the world, I see them right now.

The mothers of those Buddhas are all named MahÄmÄyÄ, their fathers are all named Åšuddhodana, their cities are all named Kapilavastu, their foremost Å›rÄvaka disciples are all named ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana, and their attendant disciples are all named Ä€nanda. How much more so for the various different named mothers, different named fathers, different named cities, different named disciples, and different named attendants.
ÅšÄriputra!

In those many worlds, in which worlds does that person place a particle, and in which worlds does he not place a particle? Those worlds, whether they are placed with a particle or not, extend from the water's edge below to the peak of existence above.
ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:

There is a second person who takes those fine particles, and the number of fine particles in those buddha lands, as many as the asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of koá¹­is of hundreds of thousands of nayutas of worlds, and goes beyond that many worlds for one step.
ÅšÄriputra!

That person goes beyond that many fine particles for one step, and that person in this way goes beyond asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of koá¹­is of hundreds of thousands of nayutas of kalpas for one step, and then places down one fine particle, in this way exhausting all the fine particles.
ÅšÄriputra!
In this way, the number of worlds, whether filled with fine particles or not, is filled with fine particles, and then again placed in the worlds of the ten directions.
ÅšÄriputra!
Moreover, beyond those worlds, whether filled with fine particles or not, those worlds, from the bottom of the water to the peak of existence, are filled with fine particles.
ÅšÄriputra!

There is a third person who takes those fine particles, and in worlds as numerous as those fine particles, makes a step. In as many hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of kalpas as there are, he walks one step. In this way, he finishes all the fine particles.
